comments.body: Do you want to say something about the fields being final?
Yeah, good idea.
Added `// Fields in a Widget subclass are always marked "final".`

Did we consider putting this comment above build() ?

I almost read this as "the following method" , because usually comments are above the thing they are commenting on.

This code is buggy. If the _MyHomePageState state has been disposed before the future completes, it'll assert.

Is there a way to cancel a pending platform request? We should do so in the state's `dispose()` function so that it doesn't unexpectedly complete here in that case.
There is no way to cancel. Added mounted check in https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/9458.
this doesn't match the style guide
Fixed in https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/9458

If we're going to add Column here we need to add comments explaining what's going on, especially if we add mainAxisSize as well.

I'm worried about having multiple versions of this template. We have four now (normal, driver, plugin, driver+plugin). We have micromanaged the creation of this template based on the usability studies; the more versions we have the more studies we're going to need to actually test them all. This doesn't scale.

I'm not sure what to do about the 'multiple versions' part. We deliberately did the conditional approach, as the alternative would have been to fork ALL ~60 files in /templates/create/ into /templates/plugin/ which would have been a lot less scalable.

Do you have a better idea than the conditional approach?

My 0.02 is that we should have two templates, a normal app project and a plugin project. The normal project should include driver support, example unit tests, ... - things we think are best practice and that we'd like to lead users towards.
We already have that. This is for the example app inside a plugin (the /example/ dir)
Ah ok. I thought this was discussing the `flutter create` case, where we do have a matrix of options.

What I mean is that right now the main.dart.tmpl file is effectively forked into four versions:
* the one generated by `flutter create`
* the one generated by `flutter create --driver` or some such
* the one generated by `flutter create --plugin` or some such
* the one hypothetically generated by `flutter create --plugin --driver` or some such (I suspect we don't ever generate this today, I haven't checked)

We have carefully crafted the one generated by `flutter create` based on usability feedback to optimise for the first hour experience. The other versions haven't been tested and I'm worried about what will happen as the needs for these various versions diverge.

To clarify, I'm not suggesting forking more. That wouldn't address my concerns (it would make in fact them worse, for the reasons discussed above by @mit-mit). My concerns are not concrete, they are merely fear for the future. :-)
Take a look at the https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/9458 PR i just sent. I think the more clear separation in main.dart makes it a little more manageable.

comments.body: What do we need this one for?
For the try/catch; that's where `PlatformException` is defined

It's unfortunate that there's no way to cancel the platformVersion call. Imagine if the call did a lot of computation, but the user triggered it then left the page that cares about the result. The work would still get done, but the result would then be thrown away.

Anyway that's an issue for another bug.
@devoncarew Can you let me know what this should now say to be accurate for IntelliJ?
The current text looks good as is :)
Great! If you change the UI, please remember to update the template :-)
